Description: Woman's face-veil (burqa) made of black crepe, doubled over at top, edged with black braid. Attached are three black cords, evenly spaced, sewn onto plaited head band of doubled cotton threads, in yellow, red and green. Brass cylindrical tube with three projecting serrated discs is suspended from central cord. This tube lies along bridge of woman's nose and is called colloquially "arusa al-burqu`" (the bride of the veil). Five small inscribed metal discs are sewn onto veil below braid.
Condition: Fair; material stained, with holes in places. Some minor stitched repairs. Discs slightly corroded.
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: Rev. William Holman Bentley
Acquisition notes: Af1994,10.1 to 21 were purchased from Miss Joyce Bentley, and described in the purchase book as "a small ethnographic collection mainly from Zaire, formed by the missionary Dr William Holman Bentley during the late XIXc."
